Situation1: They are asked to take part in an important family event like a holiday celebration or trip.
Situation2: A life-support device in the intensive care unit is flashing critical fault codes.
Story: I stared at my phone, my sister’s message glowing on the screen: “Don’t forget, we’re all meeting at Grandma’s for the holiday dinner. She’s been looking forward to seeing you.” I could almost hear my mother’s voice, gentle but firm, reminding me how much family means, how rare these moments are. I wanted to be there, to laugh with my siblings, to see Grandma’s eyes light up when I walked in. But just as I was about to reply, my work phone buzzed urgently. The hospital’s maintenance supervisor was on the line, his voice tight. “We need you now. The life-support machine in ICU is throwing critical errors. No one else can fix it.” My mind raced—lives could depend on my skills, but my family was counting on me too. The weight of both worlds pressed down, each demanding my presence, each impossible to ignore. My heart pounded as I stood frozen, torn between the people I love and the responsibility only I could fulfill.
